options.content:
At this point, the writer is considering adding the following sentence: “Scientists do not yet know all the benefits of singing, but the communal process that singing in a choir provides has many positive side effects.” Should the writer make this addition here?

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: Yes, because it reinforces the primary claim of the passage.
Yes, because it offers additional information that supports the claim of the passage.
No, because it provides information unrelated to the passage.
No, because it distracts from the focus of the previous paragraph.
disease (a prior finding independent of the 2013 study).
disease; a prior finding independent of the 2013 study.
disease: a prior finding independent of the 2013 study.

options.content:
Which choice most effectively establishes the main topic of the paragraph?

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: Singing in a choir can help prevent depression.
The brain tends to respond favorably to group singing.
Several studies show that people report feeling happier when they sing together.

options.content:
Which choice most effectively combines the sentences at the underlined portion?

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: reporting that they were suffering from clinical depression.
suffering from clinical depression by the end of that year.

options.passageText:
[1] In 2013, 32.5 million adults in the United States, roughly 10 percent of the population, sang in choirs, and England is home to more than 3,000 active choral groups. [2] Choir singing is a popular pastime. [3] These singers often report an increased sense of well-being and camaraderie, but does this hobby actually result in better health? [4] According to multiple scientific studies, singing--especially with others--provides concrete benefits to heart and brain health. [[1]]
 
A 2013 study at Sweden’s University of Gothenburg examined the heart rates of 18 young people as they sang and hummed [[2]] __for__ unison. Heart rate variability (HRV), the increase and decrease in heart rate, occurred simultaneously with subjects’ slowed breathing while singing. This combination of fluctuating heart rate and slowed breathing [[3]] __are__ called respiratory sinus arrhythmia (RSA), and it has been proven to reduce the likelihood of cardiovascular [[4]] __disease a prior finding independent of the 2013 study.__ One interesting finding from this study is that the subjects’ heartbeats synchronized while they sang together. This may be a factor in choir singers’ reported feelings of happiness and bonding.
 
[[5]] __People feel a keen sense of bonding when they sing together.__ Singing stimulates the right temporal lobe of the brain and releases [[6]] __endorphins. Endorphins blunt__ pain and engender feelings of pleasure. Cortisol, a hormonal reaction to stress and the secretion of which the brain controls, decreases after choir singing. Meanwhile, oxytocin, which the brain interprets as a feeling of emotional bonding, is increased. In a study at Oxford Brookes University, researchers surveyed 375 people who either sang alone, sang in a choir, or participated in organized sports. Those who sang in choir reported the highest levels of happiness. [[7]] __Due to__ its positive side effects, therapists have used choir singing as [[8]] __an element__ for those dealing with depression and chronic pain. A study from an arts and health research center in Canterbury, England, followed the progress of patients diagnosed with depression for a year after they joined a choir. Sixty percent of patients reported improved mental health at the end of that year, and some were no longer [[9]] __experiencing suffering from clinical depression.__
 
[[10]] From the changes in heartbeat and breathing that result in a healthier heart, to the reduction of cortisol and production of endorphins that lower stress and increase [[11]] __happiness. Choir__  singing fulfills humans by letting them create art while being part of a group.
options.passageTitle: Preaching to the Choir: the Health Benefits of Singing
